app.description: Answer some questions to find which programs can help you.
app.metaImageAlt: Screen shot of the Find financial help during COVID-19 start page
app.title: Find financial help during COVID-19
ccb.hint: Check your bank account to find out if you’ve been receiving the Canada Child Benefit. Dates of payments are available.
ccb.title: Canada Child Benefit
ccb_payment.header: Extra payment from Canada Child Benefit
cerb.header: Apply for the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB)
cesb.header: Help for students through the Canada Emergency Student Benefit (CESB)
cssg.header: Money for school if you volunteer for national service during the pandemic
dtc.1: Yes, I am a person with disabilities.
dtc.2: Yes, my child is a person with disabilities.
dtc.bullet2: Quebec Pension Plan Disability Pension, or
dtc.bullet3:
One of the disability supports provided by Veterans Affairs Canada Disability Pension:
  • Disability Pension
  • Disability Award
  • Pain and Suffering Compensation
  • Critical Injury Benefit
  • Rehabilitation Services and Vocational Assistance Program
  • Income Replacement Benefit, and/or
  • Canadian Forces Income Support
dtc.header: More money for people with disabilities
dtc.title: One-time payment to persons with disabilities
dtc_individual.featurelist.2: We expect to issue the payments beginning this fall.
dtc_individual.body.1: You are eligible for this payment if you hold a valid certificate for the Disability Tax Credit; or
dtc_individual.body.2: You are a beneficiary of one of the following as of July 1, 2020:
dtc_individual.body.2.2: Quebec Pension Plan Disability Pension, or
dtc_individual.body.2.3: One of the disability supports provided by Veterans Affairs Canada:
dtc_individual.body.2.3.5: Rehabilitation Services and Vocational Assistance Program
dtc_individual.body.3: We expect to issue the payments beginning this fall. You don’t need to do anything to receive it.
dtc_individual.infolink_text: Learn more about the Disability Tax Credit
dtc_child.header: More money for people with disabilities
dtc_child.featurelist.2: We expect to issue the payments beginning this fall.
dtc_child.body.1: You are eligible for this payment if you hold a valid certificate for the Disability Tax Credit for your child.
dtc_child.body.2: We expect to issue the payments beginning this fall. You don’t need to do anything to receive it.
dtc_child.body.3: If you share custody for your child, this payment will be split $300 to each parent.
dtc_child.infolink_text: Learn more about the Disability Tax Credit
dtc_oas.header: More money for people with disabilities
dtc_oas.featurelist.1:
• $300 one-time, tax-free payment if you received the one-time payment for the Old Age Security (OAS) pension
  • OR
  • $100 one-time tax-free payment if you received the $500 one-time seniors payment for both the OAS pension and the Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS).
dtc_oas.featurelist.2: We expect to issue the payments beginning this fall. You don’t need to do anything to receive it.
dtc_oas.body.1: You are eligible for this payment if you are a beneficiary as of July 1, 2020 of:
dtc_oas.body.1.2: Quebec Pension Plan Disability Pension, or
dtc_oas.body.1.3: One of the disability supports provided by Veterans Affairs Canada Disability Pension:
dtc_oas.body.1.3.5: Rehabilitation Services and Vocational Assistance Program
dtc_oas.infolink_text: Learn more about the Disability Tax Credit
ei_regular.header: Apply for Employment Insurance (EI) Regular Benefits
ei_regular_cerb.header: Apply for the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB)
ei_sickness_cerb.header: Apply for the Canada Emergency Response Benefit (CERB)
ei_workshare.header: Talk to your employer and coworkers about Employment Insurance (EI) Work-Sharing
ei_workshare.body.list1.title: The benefit can help if:
ei_workshare.body.list1.1: Your hours have been reduced by 10 to 60% because of COVID-19.
ei_workshare.body.list2.title: To do this:
ei_workshare.body.list2.1: You would enter into an agreement with your employer and other coworkers who do the exact same work as you.
ei_workshare.body.list2.2: All employees who do the same work need to agree to share the work equally, and your employer has to agree as well.
errors.multipleChoiceGeneric: You must select one of the options listed below
feedback-error.title: Error
feedback-thanks.title: Thanks!
feedback.3: You didn't find what you were looking for
feedback.4: Page does not work with your adaptive technologies
feedback.button: Report a problem or mistake on this page
feedback.dont_know: You don’t know where else to go for help.
feedback.error: You need to tell us something about the problem before you can submit.
feedback.personal_warning: Do not include your personal or financial details. We use this information to improve this service, but we do not reply.
feedback.question: Check all the issues that apply
feedback.go_back: To return to the previous page, click on the Back button.
form.ccb: Do you receive the Canada Child Benefit?
form.dtc: Are you or your child a person with disabilities?
form.dtc-individual: Do you hold a valid Disability Tax Credit certificate or are you a beneficiary of one of the following as of July 1, 2020:
form.dtc-child: Does your child have a valid Disability Tax Credit certificate?
form.gross_income: How much total income before taxes did you earn from paid work in 2019 or the last 12 months?
form.lost_job: Choose the description that best fits your situation.
form.mortgage_payments: Are you worried about making mortgage or rent payments?
form.oas: Are you receiving any of the following pensions?
form.plans_for_school: Are you planning to go to college or university in September 2020?
form.reduced_income: How much do you expect to earn before taxes per month now?
form.rrif: Do you have a Registered Retirement Income Fund (RRIF)?
form.student_debt: Do you have student loans you owe the government?
form.your_situation.no_income: Choose the description that best fits your situation.
form.your_situation.some_income: Choose the description that best fits your situation.
form.your_situation.unchanged_income: Choose the description that best fits your situation.
gross_income.title: Income earned
gst_credit.header: More money through the GST credit
gst_credit.featurelist.1: Automatic payment in April if you already receive the GST credit
gst_credit.featurelist.2:
On average:
  • $400 for single people
  • $600 for couples
gst_credit.featurelist.3: Amount depends on your 2018 income taxes
gst_credit.body.1: You don’t need to do anything to receive this payment. It was sent automatically if you already receive the GST credit, starting April 9.
gst_credit.body.2: Check your bank account or mailbox to see if you’ve received it.
gst_credit.infolink_text: Learn more about the GST credit
lost_job.2: Some of your income has stopped.
lost_job.3: Your income is not affected by COVID-19.
lost_job.title: Lost income due to COVID-19
mortgage_deferral.header: Contact your bank to delay mortgage payments
mortgage_payments.1: Yes, you’re worried about your mortgage.
mortgage_payments.2: Yes, you’re worried about your rent.
mortgage_payments.3: No, you’re not worried at this time.
mortgage_payments.title: Your housing
mortgage_payments.featurelist.1: Skip mortgage payments until you’re able to pay again
mortgage_payments.body.1: The bank will still charge interest.
mortgage_payments.body.2: When you’re able to pay again, you’ll have to pay the interest that was collected during the deferral, as well as your regular payments.
mortgage_payments.body.3: You can also talk to your bank about special payment arrangements or re-amortizing your mortgage.
mortgage_payments.infolink_text: Learn more about help with your mortgage
no_income.title: Your situation
oas.4: No, you’re not receiving any of these.

oas.title: Old Age Security
phase.desc: This site will change as we test ideas.

province.title: Your province or territory
reduced_income.title: Your reduced income
rent_help.header: In most provinces and territories, you cannot be evicted for not paying rent
rent_help.body.1: Provincial governments are in charge of rental housing rules.
rent_help.body.2: In most provinces and territories, you cannot be evicted for not paying rent.
rent_help.infolink_text: Check with your provincial government for more details
results.banner: You missed a couple questions at the beginning. Start over to get your full results.
results.check_back: We’re working to add more programs, so you may want to check back in the future or if your situation changes.
results.eligibility_warning: These results do not guarantee your eligibility. Read the details we link to before applying.
results.header_text: Based on what you’ve told us, the following help is available:
results.no_results.preamble: Your situation does not match any of the benefits included here at the moment. We’re working to add more programs, so you may want to check back in the future or if your situation changes.
results.other_potential_help.preamble: The following help is available as well:
results.situation_changes: If your situation changes, you can answer the questions again to get new programs.
results.unavailable_benefits_preamble: Based on what you told us, the following options do not fit your situation.
results.unavailable_close_link: Close list of benefits not relevant for you
results.unavailable_view_link: Open list of benefits not relevant for you
rrif.header: Lower mandatory withdrawals for your Registered Retirement Income Fund (RRIF)
rrif.title: RRIF
rrif.body.1: The mandatory amount you need to withdraw from your RRIF in 2020 will be 25% lower so you can save more money.
rrif.infolink_text: Contact your bank for more details
some_income.title: Your situation
start.enable_cookies_body: It looks like you have cookies disabled. This service uses cookies to show your results. You will not see results without enabling cookies.
start.enable_cookies_title: Enable cookies to use this service
start.intro.2: Here, you’ll be asked 7 to 10 questions, one at a time.
start.intro.3: Then we’ll show you a list of benefits that may help in your situation. It will also have links for more information.
start.intro.4: Please answer the questions as an individual, not a household.
start.title: Find financial help during COVID-19
student_debt.title: Student loans
student_financial_aid.header: More financial aid for 2020-21 school year
student_financial_aid.preamble: Increasing Canada Student Grants and Loans
student_financial_aid.benefitlist.1: Up to $6,000 in grants for full-time students
student_financial_aid.benefitlist.2: Up to $3,600 in grants for part-time students
student_financial_aid.benefitlist.3: Doubling grants for students with dependants
student_financial_aid.benefitlist.4: Doubling grants for students with permanent disabilities
student_financial_aid.benefitlist.5: Removing expected contributions from students and spouses
student_financial_aid.benefitlist.6: Up to $350 for the weekly amount in student loans
student_financial_aid.body.3: You can apply in your province or territory of residence.
student_financial_aid.infolink_text: Read more about financial aid for students
student_loan.header: No student loan payments for 6 months
student_loan.body.1: You don’t need to apply to pause your payments.
student_loan.body.3: Log in to your National Student Loans Service Centre account to see how much you will save.
student_loan.infolink_text: Learn more about help with student loan payments
unchanged_income.title: Your situation
wordmark.alt: Symbol of the Government of Canada
your_situation.no_income.3: You’re self-employed and have no income.
your_situation.no_income.4: You’re on unpaid leave to care for a child or sick person.
your_situation.no_income.5: You’re sick or in mandatory quarantine and on unpaid leave.
your_situation.no_income.6: You were on parental leave recently, but you cannot return to work due to COVID-19.
your_situation.no_income.7: You were a college or university student during the 2019-20 school year and now cannot find work.
your_situation.no_income.8: You were on Employment Insurance Regular or Fishing Benefits and your claim ended on or after December 29, 2019.
your_situation.some_income.1: Your employer has reduced your hours due to COVID-19.
your_situation.some_income.2: You’ve lost one or two part-time jobs and still have some income.
your_situation.some_income.3: You’re self-employed and lost some income but you still have some paid work.
your_situation.some_income.4: You’re retired and lost your part-time work.
your_situation.some_income.5: You’re sick or in mandatory quarantine and on unpaid leave.
your_situation.unchanged_income.4: You were a college or university student during the 2019-20 school year and now cannot find work.
your_situation.unchanged_income.5: You’re graduating high school in the 2019-20 school year and have applied for post-secondary education that will start before February 1, 2021.
results.oas.desc1: $300 one-time, tax-free payment if you are eligible for the Old Age Security (OAS) pension
results.oas.desc2: OR $500 one-time, tax-free payment if you receive the Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS)
results.oas.desc3: OR $500 one-time, tax-free payment if you receive the Allowance or the Allowance for the Survivor
results.oas.good_to_know1: You’ll receive this payment if you are eligible to receive OAS or its related benefits in June 2020.
results.oas.good_to_know2: You become eligible for OAS the month after you turn 65. So if you turn 65 in June, you will not receive this one-time payment.
results.oas.good_to_know3: Payments will be sent automatically, starting July 6, 2020. You don’t need to do anything to receive it.
results.oas.infolink_text: Learn more about help for seniors
